data.text: @destineybleu @lingerie_addict Sigh, I can definitely relate to that when I was at Curve 2012-2014 buying for my then online store. There were many times vendors would straight up ignore me as I tried to get information about a brand. It’s tiring how we are consistently minimized in these spaces.
@AdamantxYves @lingerie_addict @HeyAprill Oh I had no idea. Noted!

@lingerie_addict @HeyAprill @sanitythief We love you! I definitely want all the good things to happen for you.

But her? https://t.co/CwGZyIYs4d
@lingerie_addict @AdamantxYves @sanitythief And her public views on colorism were cringeworthy as well.
@HeyAprill @AdamantxYves @sanitythief I probably missed out on some context here, but the lingerie industry can be deeply unpleasant for black folks, myself included.
@lingerie_addict @sanitythief They treated her the way she treats fat Women, if we keepin it all the way real. ☕
@lingerie_addict It was a young girl too. I was like OMGGGG i love their stuff, and saw some widenets. Before I even got back to samples, she told me I could see it on the website. 💀💀
@destineybleu Thanks for sharing who it was.
@destineybleu GIRL!!! Yes! The rudeness. The clear and overt, “You don’t belong here.” signals.
@lingerie_addict People even came up to the vendor while we were placing an order and started asking them questions like we didn’t exist. LOL.
@lingerie_addict China, Japan and Thailand peeps were the most welcoming! No judgement whatsoever.

@lingerie_addict It’s one thing if you realize I can’t meet your minimum quantities, but to not even acknowledge me and then automatically assume I couldn’t purchase from you is just wrong. It was Oroblu. Someone I was really interested in working with. Especially given my clientele.
Anyway, it’s no accident that two of the biggest names in lingerie are black women - Ade Hassan of Nubian Skin and Destiney Bleu of dbleudazzled.
